dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: Backgrounded by palm trees and rolling surf, an American  army radar operator sits at his huge instrument, intently tracking a target. Without interrupting this, he speaks w tense excitement into a telephone transmitter strapped to his chest. (It is 8:00 a.m.) (In this and the subsequent scenes, music and cutting bui to an exciting crescendo).

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: A group of British soldiers, in shorts and tropical gear, are gathered tensely around a piece of radar equipment, w is tracking a target. The radar operator says something t another soldier, who turns and speaks excitedly into a fi telephone. (It is 5:00 a.m.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The microphone bears the word CALCUTTA. An Indian announc his expression one of excitement and terror, jabbers into the mike in a native tongue. A clock on the wall indicate that it is 2:26

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The plane is identified by a red star on the fuselage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The radioman is tracking an object on his radar scope. He points it out excitedly to the pilot. The pilot adjusts h microphone and starts making a report back to his base in Russian.

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: A group of French farmers is collected around a radio,  listening wide-eyed to the keyed-up voice which is tellin them, in French, of a strange object that has been seen i the sky. They exchange uneasy glances. One old man crosse himself.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: A breathless American radio reporter is speaking into his mike, but we can't hear what he's saying. On the wall beh him is a clock which reads 3:32.

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: A clock shows the time to be 8:32. The British announcer  tries to maintain his traditional BBC calm, but finds it  almost impossible to control his excitement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reports are coming in from all over  the Empire -- from all over the world.  The Government have not yet issued a  statement, but there seems to be no  question that there actually is a  large, unidentified object circling  the earth at incredible speed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This announcer keeps talking, but his voice fades out, an now we hear the words the American announcer is saying...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (staccato with  excitement) We still don't know what it is or  where it's from В–- but we do know  there's something there. It's been  tracked around the world by radar  traveling at a rate of four thousand  miles an hour.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The driver and his fare are listening intently to the rad as we hear the voice of another radio reporter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (voice off scene) This is not another "flying saucer"  scare. Scientists and military men  have already agreed on that. Whatever  this is -- it's something real.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The attendant, who is filling a car with gas, leans aroun to hear the car's radio, oblivious to the fact that the c tank is overflowing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (voice off scene) We interrupt this program to give  you a bulletin just received from  one of our naval units at sea. "A  large object, traveling at supersonic  speed, is headed over the North  Atlantic toward the east coast of  the United States."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Music builds to a climax and ends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with deliberately  controlled calm) Here in the nation's capital, there  is anxiety and concern, but no outward  sign of panic. As a matter of fact,  there are signs of normalcy that  seem strangely out of place; the  beautiful spring weather, the tourist  crowds at the various monuments and  public buildings...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small crowd of tourists is climbing the steps to the  columned entrance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Under this shot a barely audible, distant hum is heard. I grows in volume so imperceptibly in this and the next two shots that we are unconscious of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crowds are strolling on the Mall and across the well-kept lawns in front of the Smithsonian Institution with the  leisurely, meandering quality that distinguishes sight-se

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Including several small groups of people moving toward th Smithsonian. Their attention is attracted as the hum off  scene becomes a roar. The sound is unearthly in its inten and almost unbearable in its swiftly increasing volume. T people stop in their tracks and look up in the sky in ter

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Several people on the steps of the Smithsonian have turne to look. There is cold, frozen fear in their eyes. The aw sound keeps increasing in volume.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A man, following the progress of a huge object in the sky with his eyes. He is held terror-stricken.

dialogues.speaker: SKY, (SERSEN SHOT)
dialogues.text: A giant shape, still at some distance, is approaching the earth at incredible speed.

dialogues.speaker: GROUND
dialogues.text: A group of people run wildly across a large expanse of la A huge shadow cast from above onto the grass seems to be  pursing them.

dialogues.speaker: SKY, (SERSEN SHOT)
dialogues.text: The great shape is considerably nearer now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of a woman, thoroughly shaken, held immobile by what she  sees and hears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People scatter madly in all directions as the huge spaces comes in for a landing on a smooth, grassy area. The  tremendous roar of its motors is suddenly cut off and the great ship settles gently to a perfect landing.

dialogues.speaker: THE SHIP
dialogues.text: The gleaming surface of the ship shows no break of any ki no windows, no ports, not even the outline of a hatch. It a fearsome, terrifying object, giving no evidence of its  source or its intention.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shooting down on a section of lawn, showing the varying  reactions of people to the landing. Some are still runnin madly away; others, singly and in little groups, stand as though rooted, staring at the ship from a respectful dist

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: As he stares at the ship with fascination and horror. He' like to run but he can't. His mouth twitches and he emits nervous little laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A woman is holding a two-year-old child by the hand as sh watches the ship, awe-struck. Several people run past the Suddenly the woman grabs up the child with a little sob,  turns and runs away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A middle-aged man runs up to a group of several people,  pointing wildly toward the ship and yelling irrationally:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're here! They're here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He runs off toward another group as we--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A series of short DISSOLVES showing: 1. A man dashing up to a crowded Washington street corner shouting wildly and gesticulating in the direction from w he came. 2. Policemen piling into squad cars, which roar out of th garage. 3. Soldiers rushing out of a barracks at Fort Myer, with  rifles and side arms, to form up on their company street. 4. Newspaper presses rolling at high speed. 5. Newscasters chattering excitedly into their microphone 6. A large telephone switchboard with the girls in a fren of activity as they try to handle the calls pouring in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The players are standing on the field in the crowded stad but the game has been interrupted and everyone is listeni to the voice on the loudspeaker system. (Actual stock sho would be coverage of some dedication or ceremonial.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Brigadier General speaks in clipped tones into the  telephone. There are a couple of other officers in the ro

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone) Get me the Chief of Staff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A shot, if one is available, of either House listening ra as an announcement of great import is read by the Chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A distinguished-looking government official speaks into t phone with a sense of subdued urgency.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to speak to the President. (listens for a moment) I'm sorry -- you'll have to interrupt  him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A nationally known news commentator -- for purposes of th script let's say Drew Pearson -- is seated before a radio mike. He is also being photographed by TV cameras. In a w near him is a TV screen which shows what is going out on air. During the ensuing speech, a man comes in a hands hi sheaf of news bulletins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen,  this is Drew Pearson. We bring you  this special radio-television  broadcast to give you the latest  information on the landing of the  "space ship" in Washington.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Government and Defense Department  officials are concerned by reports  of panic in several large Eastern  cities. I am authorized to assure  you that so far there is no reasonable  cause for alarm. The rumors of  invading armies and mass destruction  are based on hysteria and are  absolutely false. I repeat -- these  rumors are absolutely false!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ship, designed for travel outside  the earth's atmosphere, landed in  Washington today at 3:47 p.m., Eastern  Standard Time. We still don't know  where it came from, but I can reveal  that military leaders are considering  two possibilities; that it came from  some unfriendly power here on earth --  or that it actually arrived from  another planet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA PANS to and DOLLIES IN on the TV screen in the wal On the screen is a shot of the space ship.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (over scene) The ship is resting exactly where it  landed two hours ago, and there has  been no sign of life from inside it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OUR CAMERAL HOLDS on the TV screen. The cuts that follow inside the frame of the screen:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two platoons of infantry soldiers surround the ship, thei rifles at the ready.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (over scene) Troops have been rushed from Fort  Myer and they have formed a cordon  around the ship.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: showing two machine guns, two Sherman tanks and two 75MM  guns. The gun crews are posted for action and all weapons are trained on the space ship.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (over scene) They are supported by machine guns,  tanks and artillery.

dialogues.speaker: POLICE CORDON
dialogues.text: Cops are holding back a section of a large crowd, some  distance away from the ship. The people are wide-eyed and tense with excitement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (over scene) Behind police lines, there is a large  crowd of curiosity seekers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 1. Civilians in the crowd, their eyes and nerves taut wit suspense. 2. A young soldier, who grips his rifle and moistens his  lips nervously, his eyes never leaving the ship. 3. A tank commander blinks from the tension of staring at unmoving object. 4. The last cut is of the ship itself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (over scene) As you can see for yourself, the  Army has taken every precaution to  meet whatever the situation may  require. Every eye -- every weapon --  is trained on the ship. It's been  this way for two hours and the tension--

dialogues.speaker: PEARSON
dialogues.text: as he interrupts himself excitedly, his attention riveted the TV screen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just a minute, ladies and gentlemen!  I think I see something moving!

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: We are at the actual location now, not looking at TV. We the ship surrounded by soldiers, two medium tanks, two  artillery pieces, and a couple of machine guns. Some dist away is a suggestion of the crowd of civilians, held back police. Prominent in the scene are newsreel and televisio cameras. OUR CAMERA MOVES IN to MED. SHOT. As it does so, see a couple of metal objects rising slowly from the top the ship. One, which is an oddly-designed coil of wire, s up and revolves slowly. The other is a section of vented  pipe with a convex cap on it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: on the soldiers, their eyes glued to this first sign of  activity from the ship. They shift uneasily, gripping the rifles more firmly.

dialogues.speaker: THE SHIP
dialogues.text: After a long, tense moment, a ramp appears silently out o the side of the ship and slides down to the ground. There an audible gasp as a man appears at the top of the ramp. looks around at the crowd with cool and imperturbable dig This is KLAATU. He is completely human in appearance. The only unearthly thing about him is his clothing. He wears tunic that is very good looking, but at the same time  thoroughly comfortable and practical. On his head is a me helmet that obscures most of his face. (It would be impos to identify him later.) The design of this helmet gives t impression that it is more a formal headdress than for  protection. Klaatu is above all an impressive man -- a ma of tremendous dignity and presence. He has the tolerant  superiority that comes with absolute knowledge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: of soldiers, people in the crowd, and policemen. The news and TV men are busy at their cameras.

dialogues.speaker: KLAATU
dialogues.text: After an impressive moment, he raises his arms in the  universal gesture of neutrality. Then he speaks, in perfe English, his voice amplified as though through an enuncia

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have come to visit you in peace --  and with good will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Klaatu walks slowly down the ramp toward the soldiers. As does so, he draws from inside his tunic a strange looking object, longish and tubular. It might be a a telescope -- it might be some strange kind of weapon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: shooting from the side, showing Klaatu advancing slowly t the line of soldiers. He holds out the mysterious object front of him in a gesture that is actually one of offerin but could be misinterpreted as menacing. There is a growi uneasy rumble of muttering among the soldiers as Klaatu  advances. They are clearly frightened of what he may do.

dialogues.speaker: PLATOON LEADER
dialogues.text: A young second lieutenant, standing in front of his plato As Klaatu advances, the lieutenant unslings his carbine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Klaatu starts toward the platoon leader, raising the obje he holds toward the man, trying to make clear his intenti Misinterpreting this as a menacing gesture, the platoon l raises his carbine to his shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: of one of the tank commanders in the turret of his tank. is watching Klaatu advancing toward the platoon leader an he has drawn his pistol. Convinced that the lieutenant is jeopardy, the tank commander aims at Klaatu and fires.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Klaatu falls to the ground wounded. The object he was  holding has dropped from his hand and smashed. The soldie start to gather around Klaatu excitedly when suddenly the appears in the entrance to the space ship a huge robot. T is a gasp of amazement from the crowd and the solders dra back at sight of him. The robot is ten feet tall, is made the almost-perfect image of a man. He is to be played by actor and his flesh appears to be made of a greenish meta His eyes flash as though lighted internally. His perfectl fashioned, muscular body is covered only with a loincloth This is GORT. There are cries of amazement as Gort walks slowly pondero down the ramp to the ground. As he does so, the ramp clos behind him. Gort's face is, and always remains, utterly  expressionless. He stops to look at Klaatu, lying on the  ground. Then he looks around at the soldiers, the tanks a guns. All the guns have been traversing to follow him.

dialogues.speaker: GORT
dialogues.text: From inside him there comes an ominous crackling sound, a though power were being generated within him. His eyes fl toward the tank from which Klaatu was shot.

dialogues.speaker: TANK
dialogues.text: There is a great metallic clatter and the Sherman tank is suddenly reduced to a pile of junk metal, its parts compl disintegrated. Only a piece of tank track and twisted gun barrel emerge from the heap on the ground to identify wha had been there. The tank's crew has remained unharmed.

dialogues.speaker: GORT
dialogues.text: The crackling sound continues as his eyes start to sweep a semicircle taking in all the troops.

dialogues.speaker: THE TROOPS
dialogues.text: SHOOTING FROM BEHIND Gort, with the back of his head in f CAMERA PANS to follow Gort's sweeping gaze. In a growing  crash and clatter of metal, every weapon in sight is  destroyed. The two machine guns are little heaps of junk. The 75's are larger heaps. The second tank, like the firs is a three-foot pile of scrap. Rifles have dropped from t soldier's hands and lie on the ground as little mounds of wood and metal. None of the men has been harmed, but thei faces show the utter terror of what they have experienced

dialogues.speaker: THE TROOPS
dialogues.text: as they react to the full shock of what has happened. Mos of them stand rooted to the ground. Several laugh  hysterically. A few break and run wildly.

dialogues.speaker: CROWD OF CIVILIANS
dialogues.text: Sudden pandemonium breaks out. Utterly terrified by what  they have witnessed, the crowd becomes a wild, milling,  screaming mob, concerned only with escape.

dialogues.speaker: GORT
dialogues.text: He is walking slowly, deliberately, menacingly toward the tank commander who fired on Klaatu. Standing by the debri of his tank, the man is immobilized with terror. The robo starts to reach out to grab him.

dialogues.speaker: KLAATU
dialogues.text: lying on the ground. He speaks to Gort sharply, in a stra language.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gort! Deglet ovrosco!

dialogues.speaker: GORT
dialogues.text: He pauses obediently in the act of reaching out for the t commander. Dropping his arms, he stands motionless and re that way.

dialogues.speaker: KLAATU
dialogues.text: He has raised himself to a sitting position on the ground his wounded shoulder giving him considerable pain. The tw platoon leaders come into scene hesitantly, badly shaken the awesome demonstration of power they have seen. They a uncertain as to what they should do. The platoon leader e the smashed object on the ground curiously and turns  questioningly to Klaatu. With great dignity, Klaatu picks the broken object, which we see well for the first time. is a delicately-made tubular telescope, badly smashed. On are indications of small electronic gadgets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was a gift. For your President. (glances at the broken  object ruefully) With this he could have studied life  on other planets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Klaatu lets the object drop with a shrug of mild exaspera The two lieutenants exchange a helpless look of bewilderm Then Klaatu raises himself to his feet painfully, holding his wounded shoulder. As he does so, a colonel and a capt come into scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the lieutenants) Is he all right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got hit in the shoulder, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The three junior officers exchange ineffectual glances an look to the colonel, who thinks for a moment before makin his decision.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Send for an ambulance. Get him to  Walter Reed Hospital right away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a door to the corridor and a door to Klaatu's ro In the small sitting room, talking in tones of hushed con is a group of men. There's a Major General, a likable man with a chest full of ribbons. There are also a Colonel in command of the hospital, a high-ranking police officer, a couple of medical officers and two civilians. The convers is interrupted by the entrance from Klaatu's room of a Me Corps Major, followed by an Army Nurse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Major) How is he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's all right, General... Blood  pressure's a little high, but it  could be aggravation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (wryly) Can't blame him. I always get mad  when somebody shoots me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He still wants to see the President.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to General) We informed the White House over an  hour ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Major) Didn't drop any hints about where  he's from, did he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, sir, he didn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door to the corridor opens and a worried young Captai enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me. (to the Colonel) What about the reporters, Colonel?  They're swarming all over the lobby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Colonel turns, in deference, to the General.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly) Tell them there won't be any statement  tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. (glancing down the  corridor) Mr. Harley's here from the White  House.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harley appears in the doorway, a brief case under his arm He's a dignified, intelligent member of the White House  secretariat. He proceeds uninterruptedly into the room,  nodding cordially to the General.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: General --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (indicating Klaatu's  room) Right in there, Mr. Harley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harley proceeds in businesslike fashion to the door. He k and then enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Harley enters, closing the door behind him. Klaatu no  longer wears his helmet and we see his face clearly for t first time. Even sitting up in bed, with his shoulder str in bandages, he is a figure of great authority. His face  reflects inner dignity and assurance. Harley, who is a  hardened diplomatist, can't help being impressed by his  present assignment and a little awed by Klaatu. Harley  obviously has been sent by the President to find out what can. Klaatu's eyes study him, cool, penetrating, reserved

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My name is Harley -- Secretary to  the President (Klaatu continues to  study him silently) I've been told that you speak our  language -- that your name is Mr.  Klaatu.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (coolly) Just Klaatu.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The President asked me to convey his  deepest apologies for what has  happened. We all feel--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (evenly) Sit down, Mr. Harley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somewhat relieved, Harley seats himself. He speaks with a half smile, hoping to ease the tension.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure I don't have to point out  that your arrival was something of a  surprise. (getting a little  smile from Klaatu,  he is encouraged to  do some fishing) Had you been traveling long?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About five months -- your months.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must have come a long way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About 250 million of your miles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harley glances at him quickly to be sure he's not joking. He's not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naturally we're very curious to know  where it is you come from.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (easily; he's a  diplomat, too) From another planet. Let's just say  that we're neighbors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harley reacts, as his wildest assumptions are so blandly  corroborated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's rather difficult for us to think  of another planet as a neighbor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm afraid, in the present situation  you'll have to learn to think that  way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (eyebrows raised) The present situation?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean the reasons for my coming  here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (his eagerness apparent) We're very curious about that, too.  Would you care to talk about it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd be glad to. (noticing that Harley  is settling himself  expectantly) Not now, of course -- with you alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps you'd rather discuss it  personally with the President--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (somewhat sharply) This is not a personal matter, Mr.  Harley. It concerns all the people  on your planet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Startled by the scope  of this statement) I -- I'm not sure I understand--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to meet with representatives  from all the nations of the Earth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shocked and perturbed  by this notion) I'm afraid that would be a little  awkward. It's -- it's completely  without precedent. And there are  practical considerations -- the time  involved -- the enormous distances.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (coolly) I traveled 250 million miles. What  about your United Nations?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Surprised and a little  puzzled) You know about the United Nations?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've been monitoring your radio  broadcasts for a good many years.  That's how we learned your languages.  Lately, we've been getting your  television also.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (wryly) You must have a rather strange  impression of us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling) The first two years of television we  were convinced that all you did was  wrestle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harley smiles. Then his mind reverts to the seriousness o the situation and he speaks gravely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure you recognize from our broad- casts the evil forces that have  produced the tension in our world.  Surely you would agree--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (evenly) I am not concerned, Mr. Harley, with  the internal affairs of your planet.  I consider that to be your business --  not mine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was only hoping to make you  understand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sternly, impressively) My mission here is not to solve your  petty squabbles. It concerns the  existence of every last creature who  lives on Earth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (uncomfortably) Perhaps if you could explain a little--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I intend to explain. To all the  nations -- simultaneously. (his manner precludes  opposition) How do we proceed, Mr. Harley?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harley is thoroughly shaken. The tremendous force and pow implicit in Klaatus's manner preclude the possibility of  argument.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a long  thoughtful moment) We could call a special meeting of  the General Assembly... But of course  the UN doesn't represent all of the  nations.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then why not a meeting of all the  Chiefs of State?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (helplessly, but  patiently) Believe me, you don't understand.  They wouldn't sit down at the same  table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Growing a little impatient with such nonsense, Klaatu eye him evenly, speaks with Jovian authority.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want to resort to threats,  Mr. Harley. I simply tell you bluntly  that the future of your planet is at  stake... I suggest you transmit that  message to the nations of the Earth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The eyes of the two men meet for a long, silent moment. T Harley rises quietly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will make that recommendation to  the President. (he picks up his brief  case and hat) I must tell you in all honesty that  I'm extremely dubious about the  results.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a half-smile) Apparently I'm not as cynical about  Earth's people as you are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been dealing in Earth's politics  a good deal longer than you have. (he bows) Goodnight, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns and goes out.

dialogues.speaker: KLAATU
dialogues.text: He stares after Harley for a moment, puzzled by this stra and apparently unreasoning world he has come to. He shake his head in thoughtful, tolerant bewilderment.

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: Searchlights have lighted up up the eerie shapes of the s ship and Gort. A circle of soldiers guard the area, while crew of men can be seen working around the ship.

dialogues.speaker: AT SHIP
dialogues.text: A Master Sergeant of Engineers, dressed in fatigues, is  inspecting the side of the ship carefully. He has an acet torch in his had and a welding helmet over his face. The  Major General, previously seen in the hospital sitting ro enters and speaks to the Sergeant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Getting any place, Sergeant?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (raising his helmet) No, sir. (shaking his head in  annoyance) Beats me, General. I saw that ramp  come out of the side of the ship --  right here. Now I can't even find a  crack!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A man named Carlson, a civilian metallurgical expert, com into scene. The General nods to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the report, Carlson?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (discouraged) We've tried everything from a  blowtorch to a diamond drill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nodding toward Gort) What about him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's made out of the same stuff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Has he moved?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No sir. Not an inch

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the toughest material I ever  saw, General. For hardness and  strength, it's out of this world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a wry half-smile) I can tell you officially -В– that's  where it came from.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two men exchange an uneasy glance, then turn to look the ship.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two Medical Corps officers, a Captain and a Major are  interestedly studying a series of X-ray films.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The skeletal structure is completely  normal. (pointing) Same for the major organs -В– heart,  liver, spleen, kidneys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the lungs are the same as ours.  Must mean a similar atmosphere --  similar pressure. (nodding, toward  Klaatu's room) How old do you think he is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I'd say forty-five.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling) He told me this morning when I  examined him. He's seventy-eight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't believe it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Their life expectancy is a hundred  and thirty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How does he explain that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He says their medicine is that much  more advanced. (the major stares at  him blankly) He was very nice about it. But he  made me feel like a third-class witch  doctor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door to Klaatu's rooms opens and Major White appears. He's the man who attended Klaatu the day before. He close the door behind him and stands motionless facing the othe two, his face wearing a blank expression.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I took a bullet out of that man's  arm yesterday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (utterly bewildered) I just examined the wound and it's  all healed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What does he say about it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Said he put some salve on it -- some  stuff he had with him. (shows them a small,  odd-looking tube in  his hand)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you going to do with it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take it downstairs and have it  analyzed. (on his way to the  door, shaking his  head) Then I don't know whether I'll just  get drunk or give up the practice of  medicine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he starts out the door to the corridor, he passes Mr.  Harley, who is on his way in, carrying his ever-present b case. Harley is accompanied by an enlisted M.P.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Afternoon, Mr. Harley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Afternoon, gentlemen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harley goes to the door of Klaatu's room, a businesslike  expression on his face. He knocks on the door, then enter The M.P. remains in the sitting room.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: as Harley enters. Klaatu is up out of bed, walking around a Medical Corps robe and pajamas. He appears to be comple recovered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good afternoon. (surprised not to  find him in bed) I'm glad to see you up and around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you... Have you any news?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not very good news, I'm afraid. (digs into his  briefcase for some  papers) The President accepted your suggestion  and cabled the invitations for a  meeting last night. (grimly) Let me read you some of the replies. (he selects a cable  and reads) "The Premier wishes to inform the  Government of the United States that  it will be impossible for him to  attend the meeting suggested by the  President unless the meeting is held  in Moscow." (with a grimly-pointed  glance at Klaatu,  Harley reads another  cable) "The suggestion of the President  regarding the possibility of a meeting  in Moscow would be unacceptable to  Her Majesty's Government at the  present time. Representation could  be sent only if the meeting were  held in Washington." (he looks up at Klaatu  and shrugs) Well -- there you have it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harley extends a sheaf of cables for Klaatu's inspection, but he ignores them. Klaatu has listened to this recital, first incredulously, then with mounting indignation. Cons of his quiet, Olympian wrath, Harley continues uncomforta

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I tried to make you understand. The  suspicions -- the jealousies -- the  mistrust-- (uneasily, under  Klaatu's level gaze) Surely you realize that my government  has done everything in its power--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not your government I'm thinking  about. It's your world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now that you understand the situation  more clearly, perhaps you'd like to  discuss the matter with the President

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sternly) I will not speak to any one nation  or group of nations. (sharply, bitterly) I don't intend to add my contribution  to your childish jealousies and  suspicions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our problems are very complex, Mr.  Klaatu. You mustn't judge us too  harshly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can judge only by what I see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your impatience is quite  understandable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sharply) I am impatient with stupidity. My  people have learned to live without  it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (ruefully) I'm afraid my people haven't. (with real sincerity) I'm very sorry -- I wish it were  otherwise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reluctantly Harley has picked up his hat and brief case. finds Klaatu staring out the window.

dialogues.speaker: KLAATU
dialogues.text: As he looks out the window thoughtfully. What he sees has given him an idea.

dialogues.speaker: HOSPITAL GROUNDS
dialogues.text: shooting down, from Klaatu's viewpoint, at people strolli about the hospital grounds. Most of them are civilian  visitors, but there is a sprinkling of nurses and ambulat patients.

dialogues.speaker: HOSPITAL ROOM
dialogues.text: As Klaatu turns back to Harley, he speaks thoughtfully,  incisively.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Before making any decisions, I think  I should get out among your people --  become familiar with the basis for  these strange, unreasoning attitudes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Under the circumstances I'm afraid  that will be impossible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harley has paused near the door, a little embarrassed by  Klaatu's level gaze.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I must ask that you don't attempt to  leave the hospital. Our military  people have insisted on this. I'm  sure you'll understand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With a polite nod, he goes out. Klaatu stares after him a he realizes that he is in effect a prisoner. He shakes hi head slowly, thoughtfully. The ways of this planet are st indeed.

dialogues.speaker: AT DOOR
dialogues.text: Harley has paused to watch as the M.P. takes out a key an inserts it in the lock of Klaatu's door.

dialogues.speaker: KLAATU
dialogues.text: As he hears the click of the lock, he turns toward the do Realizing they've locked him in, he smiles with tolerant  amusement.

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: In the dim light of one lamp, the door to the corridor op and a nurse enters carrying a tray of medication. She is  accompanied by the same M.P. as previously seen. The nurs pauses as the M.P. takes out a key and inserts it in the  lock of Klaatu's door. To his surprise he finds that the  door is not locked. He exchanges a glance with the nurse, then pulls the door open and hurries inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as the M.P. crosses the unlighted room toward the bed. Th only light cones from the open door to the sitting room. M.P.'s eyes go wide as he looks at the bed. It is unmade unoccupied. Terrified, the M.P. turns to the nurse, who i standing in the doorway. M.P.  He's gone! The M.P. dashes out of the room, through the doorway past the nurse. She turns to follow him as we--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A series of short DISSOLVES, showing: 1. The M.P. excitedly reporting Klaatu's disappearance to the Officer of the Day. 2. The hospital guard detail hurrying out of the guardhou to form up in front of the Sergeant of the guard. 3. A high-level military conference gathered at a table,  discussing the matter with great concern. 4. A street corner newsstand, with people eagerly grabbin papers. The headline reads: "MAN FROM MARS" ESCAPES FROM

dialogues.speaker: ARMY HOSPITAL
dialogues.text: 5. Radio announcers chattering excitedly into their  microphones 6. A series of close-ups of people listening to the radio Their faces reveal their awestruck terror. 7. A terrified mother drags her two children in from the  street through the front door, slams the door and bolts i

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: CAMERA is on the back of a man dressed in a business suit who is walking along the sidewalk of a dimly lighted, alm deserted, middle-class street. He carries a suitcase and glances idly at the drab-looking stone facades of the old two-story houses. As he passes, from the open windows of houses come the voices of radio announcers. We get a sent or two from one house and then, as the man and our CAMERA pass on, this voice fades and another is picked up. We ge the impression that everyone is glued to his radio.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (over scene) --authorities at Walter Reed Hospital  refused to comment on how he managed  to escape, or what measures might be  taken to apprehend him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --these fantastic descriptions of the creature are denoun as rumor by police Chief Walter Baxter. He is not eight f tall, as reported -- nor does he have tentacles in place arms-- --there's no denying that there is a monster at large --  that we are dealing with forces beyond our knowledge and  power. The public is urged to take ordinary precautions a to remain calm, as we await further developments-- --three separate reports of people who claim to have seen the "space man" in the past hour. One from Des Moines, Io one from a village in northern Florida; and one from Chic CAMERA OVERTAKES the man as he pauses under the light of street lamp, and reveals that it is Klaatu. He has stoppe to look at something out of scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: from Klaatu's viewpoint, of a sign on one of the houses,  reading: ROOM FOR RENT

dialogues.speaker: KLAATU
dialogues.text: He seems to hesitate, debating a plan he has in mind. He  raises his right arm to scratch his head thoughtfully, an notices for the first time a small tag, or ticket, attach to the inside of the right forearm of the coat he is wear Puzzled, he pulls off the ticket and looks at it.

dialogues.speaker: TICKET
dialogues.text: It is the sort of tag a cleaning establishment attaches t clothing. Printed on it is the legend: CAPITOL DRY CLEANI SERVICE. Scrawled in a penciled hand is the notation: Dr. Carpenter, Bldg. A - Walter Reed Hospital. Cl. & pr.

dialogues.speaker: KLAATU
dialogues.text: He smiles wryly at this reminder of where he got the suit and he destroys the ticket. He glances down at the suitca beside him.

dialogues.speaker: SUITCASE
dialogues.text: It bears the initials L.M.C. Klaatu's hand comes into sce and lifts up the suitcase. CAMERA HOLDS as Klaatu carries the bag toward the house and mounts the stone steps to th entrance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There 's no light in the room except what splashes in fro the hall. Gathered around a television set are five adult and a little boy, their faces eerie in the reflected ligh from the screen. The room is done in average boardinghous style -- antimacassars and all. The attention of the peop is riveted on the television screen, where a newscaster i reading a bulletin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --while the President made no effort  to minimize the crisis, he urged  people all over the country to remain  calm. He said the entire facilities  of FBI and other federal agencies  are being bought to bear. He pointed  out, however, that this is no ordinary  man hunt. He warned we may be up  against powers that are beyond our  control.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The landlady, a stern-faced woman of middle age, named MR CROCKETT, rises nervously and crosses to the television s

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (tensely) I can't stand any more of this. It's  enough to drive a person crazy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She snaps off the set sharply.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BOBBY BENSON, a bright-eyed, eleven-year-old, is seated b his mother, HELEN BENSON, an attractive girl of thirty.  Disappointed that the set has been turned off, Bobby's ro eye has fallen on something in the doorway to the hall... Wide-eyed, he nudges his mother and points.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Mom -- who's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: including the doorway to the hall. Silhouetted motionless against the light from the hall is the figure of a man. A eyes follow Hobby's pointed finger, and there is a stifle gasp as they are startled out of their preoccupation. One the men turns on the lights and Klaatu is revealed standi calmly in the doorway. There is a shocked silence for a  moment, then Mrs. Crockett speaks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (apologizing nervously  for the tension in  the room) I -- I'm sorry. What is it you want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My name is Carpenter. I'm looking  for a room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a noticeable letdown in the general tension, dur which Booby has been studying Klaatu, his imagination wor overtime.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you an FBI man?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No -- I'm afraid not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Helen has stepped forward to make Bobby desist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bet he is, Mom. Bet he's out looking  for that space man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with an apologetic  smile at Klaatu) I think we've all been hearing too  much about "space men."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Crockett reverts to her role as landlady. She likes think of her house as a home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (starting the  introductions with  Helen) This is Mrs. Benson, Mr. Carpenter. (with a smile that  would split a brick) And little Bobby. (indicating a middle- aged couple and a  younger but more  wizened man) Mr. and Mrs. Barley -- and Mr.  Krull... I'm Mrs. Crockett.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are polite noddings and how-do-you-do's. Mrs. Crock is satisfied that she's established a cozy atmosphere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pleased to the point  of challenge) Well -- this is our little family. (then, getting down  to business) I have a very nice room on the second  floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She leads the way toward the hall and Klaatu starts to fo picking up his suitcase, when he is intercepted by Bobby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I help you look for the space  man? Can I? (excitedly) I know what he looks like! He's got  a square head -- and, three great  big eyes!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (good-naturedly,  calming him down) That's enough, Bobby. I think it's  time you went to bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Bobby, with a  prop smile) We mustn't annoy Mr. Carpenter -- or  he won't want to stay here. She goes  on into the hall, followed by Klaatu,  who has exchanged a polite smile  with Helen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Mrs. Crockett leads the way up the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's really a dear little boy -- and  quiet as a mouse. (with a shrewd, chatty  smile) You're a long way from home, aren't  you, Mr. Carpenter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How did you know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pleased with her  cleverness) Oh, I can tell a New England accent  a mile away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Five of the boarders -- Mr. and Mrs. Barley, Mr. Krull, H Benson and Klaatu - are finishing their Sunday morning  breakfast. Mrs. Barley is a middle-class Helen Hokinson l form and unrelenting. Her husband is a born complainer. M Krull is a shriveled little accountant, precise and finic As they finish their coffee, all except Helen are immerse in the Sunday papers. Helen seems preoccupied with her ow thoughts. From a portable radio on the table comes Gabrie Heater's voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --and so, this Sunday morning, we  ask the question that's been plaguing;  the entire nation for two days now:  "Where is this creature and what is  he up to?" If he can build a space  ship that can fly to Earth -- and a  robot that can destroy our tanks and  guns -- what other terrors can he  unleash at will? ...Obviously we  must find this monster. We must track  him down like a wild animal and  destroy him.

dialogues.speaker: NEWSPAPER PAGE IN MRS. BARLEY'S HANDS
dialogues.text: It is a full page layout, in the style of the American We showing a demented artist's conception of a mass invasion space ships. Weird-looking creatures are slaughtering Ear people with ray guns. The caption at the top of the image reads: "Are We Long For This World?" (Gabriel Heater's vo continues uninterruptedly over this and the next two scen

dialogues.speaker: KLAATU
dialogues.text: He is reading his paper with considerable interest.

dialogues.speaker: NEWSPAPER STORY
dialogues.text: The third-page story reads: SAVANT CALLS MEETING TO STUDY SPACE SHIP. Professor Jacob Barnhardt, world-famous scien and Nobel Prize winner, has invited fellow scientists fro all over the world to meet with him in Washington and stu the recently landed "Space Ship."

dialogues.speaker: KLAATU
dialogues.text: His face is thoughtful as he finishes reading. This story seems to impress and interest him. Then suddenly he finds his attention caught at what the Radio Voice is saying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But where would such a creature hide  himself? Would he disappear into the  north woods? Or would he slither off  into the sewers of some great city?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Klaatu has a reaction of affronted dignity at this monstr distasteful idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is grave danger -- everyone  agrees to that. The question is what  can we do to protect ourselves? What  measures can we take that will--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: During the above, Mrs. Barley has turned to her husband i sharp annoyance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George, I wish you'd turn that radio  off. I'm trying to concentrate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Barley reaches out and snaps off the radio.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (snorting, he tosses  his paper down) Why doesn't the Government do  something -- that's what I want to  know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mildly) What can they do? They're only people --  Just like us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People my foot! They're Democrats!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's enough to give you the shakes.  He's got that robot standing there --  ten-foot tall -- just waiting for  orders to destroy us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (thoughtfully) This space man -- or whatever he is.  We automatically assume he's a  menace... Maybe he isn't at all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (glaring at her for  this silly notion) Then what's he hiding for? Why doesn't  he come out in the open?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. (indicating the radio) Like the fella says: "What's he up  to?"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe he's afraid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a derisive snort) He's afraid!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After all, he was shot the moment he  landed here. (she pauses for a  moment thoughtfully) I was just wondering what I would  do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Helen, helpfully) Perhaps before deciding on a course  of action, you'd want to know more  about the people here -- to orient  yourself in a strange environment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sharply) There's nothing strange about  Washington, Mr. Carpenter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly, tongue in  cheek) A person from another planet might  disagree with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you want my opinion, he came from  right here on Earth. (with significant  emphasis) And you know where I mean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They wouldn't come in a space ship.  They'd come in airplanes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as though with  superior knowledge) I wouldn't be so sure about that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (delivering the final  word) Stands to reason that fella wants  some thing or he wouldn't be here. (facing Klaatu) That make sense, Carpenter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Klaatu pauses for a moment, then recites pleasantly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I must admit I'm a little confused.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Crockett enters and speaks to Helen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Benson -- Mr. Stevens is here  to see you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh -- thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She rises and goes out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Finish your coffee, George. I told  the Carsons we'd be there at eleven.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Helen crosses the room to greet TOM STEVENS. He's a  personable young man with a breezy manner and considerabl charm. There is between them an easy air of Intimacy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling warmly) Good morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom kisses her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're all set. I picked up some  sandwiches and put gas in the car.  And the radio's still busted, so me  can forget about the space man for  today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a little disturbed) There's only one thing -- I haven't  been able to arrange for anyone to  stay with Bobby. (tentatively) I don't suppose we could take him  with us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (understandably  unenthusiastically) Well, we could--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's always somebody here, but  today of course they've all got plans.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I haven't any plans.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Helen and Tom turn in surprise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: including Klaatu, who has wandered in from the dining roo unnoticed by Tom and Helen. Klaatu continues, with an air wanting to be helpful without wanting to interfere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd be glad to spend the day with  him -- if you'd let me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (impulsively) Say, that'll be great! Wouldn't it,  Helen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hesitating, a little  confused, by the  offer) It's awfully nice of you to suggest  it. (remembering the two  men haven't met) I'm sorry Mr. Carpenter -- this is  Tom Stevens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two men shake hand's and exchange how-do-you-do's. Th Klaatu turns back to Helen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobby and I had a fine time yesterday  afternoon. We talked -- and listened  to the radio. (smiling at Helen) I thought today he might show me  around the city.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Helen is debating the matter in her mind, concerned about leaving Bobby with a comparative stranger, but tempted be of her favorable impression of Klaatu.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (easily) Suppose I ask Bobby how he feels  about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns, with a little smile, and starts out of the room Helen, still not quite decided, turns to Tom with a  questioning look. Tom nods.

dialogues.speaker: DAY, (STOCK)
dialogues.text: The great seated, brooding figure of Lincoln is at the fa end of the impressive main hall. A few tourists are movin about the place.

dialogues.speaker: KLAATU AND BOBBY
dialogues.text: They are in the south hall, on the wall of which is inscr the Gettysburg Address. They stand silently, side by side reading the inscription.

dialogues.speaker: GETTYSBURG ADDRESS, (STOCK)
dialogues.text: Featuring the last part of the Address. It reads: "--and  that government of the people, by the people, for the peo shall not perish from the earth."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (visibly impressed) Those are great words. (with an air of  discovery) He must have been a great man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobby is impressed by the depth and sincerity of Klaatu's tribute, but a little confused by his air of having disco Lincoln. Hobby watches Klaatu with a puzzled expression,  then follows as Klaatu moves off slowly.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: shooting against one of the huge fluted columns as Klaatu and Bobby come out of the building. Deeply preoccupied, K speaks with impatient urgency.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the kind of man I'd like to  talk to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobby looks up at him in bewilderment. After a moment Kla speaks slowly, thoughtfully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobby -- who's the greatest man in  America today?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (puzzling it over) Gee -- I don't know... The space  man, I guess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (secretly amused) I was speaking of earth men. I meant  the greatest philosopher -- the  greatest thinker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean the smartest man in the  whole world?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes -- that would do nicely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a moments  thought) Well -- Professor Barnhardt, I guess.  He's the greatest scientist in the  world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (he pauses  thoughtfully, speaks  slowly, as he recalls  the newspaper story  he read) He lives here in Washington, doesn't  he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. Right near where my mother  works.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where is that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Department of Commerce. She's a  secretary. (Klaatu nods) They have a man they call the  Secretary, but he isn't at all. My  mother's a real secretary. (after a moment;  eagerly) Mr. Carpenter -- now can we go see  the space ship?

dialogues.speaker: SPACE SHIP AND GORT
dialogues.text: A crew of Army engineers is in process of erecting a temp structure such as a large Quonset hut or B29 hanger to en the space ship and Gort. The walls are partially up and  already have concealed part of the ship. The area is rope off and there are Army guards to keep the sightseers back There is a crowd of people behind the ropes, watching. CA MOVES IN to reveal the backs of Bobby and Klaatu.

dialogues.speaker: KLAATU AND BOBBY
dialogues.text: Bobby is studying the ship and Gort eagerly, his imaginat thoroughly aroused. Klaatu is watching the men at work wi mild, quiet amusement.

dialogues.speaker: GORT
dialogues.text: from Bobby's viewpoint.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY AND KLAATU
dialogues.text: Bobby's eyes are wide with awe as he watches the giant ro

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boy, I'll bet he's strong. I bet he  could knock down a whole building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a quizzical  smile) I shouldn't be at all surprised.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobby's attention shifts to the ship.

dialogues.speaker: SPACE SHIP
dialogues.text: From Bobby's viewpoint.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (excitedly, indicating  the ship) Gee, I'd like to get inside and see  how it works. What do you think makes  it go?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly, after a  glance around) Well -- atomic power, I would imagine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking at Klaatu  incredulously) I thought that was only for bombs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. It's for a lot of other things,  too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think it can go faster than an F- 36?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes -- I think so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: shooting from a side angle to include a couple of men who are listening to Klaatu's conversation. They are nudging  each other, amused at the way this man is pretending to  explain things to the little boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About a thousand miles an hour?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Klaatu has noticed the two men, who have edged a little c to listen. He is not perturbed by them, but he lowers his voice a bit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe four thousand miles an hour.  And outside the Earth's atmosphere a  good deal faster.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (excitedly) Gee! How could they make a landing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well -- there are several ways to  reduce landing speed. You see, the  velocity--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Klaatu interrupts himself as he realizes that he may be g too far. The two men have moved closer, listening and  grinning. One of them whispers to the other behind the ba of his hand. Then the man realizes that Klaatu has stoppe speaking and is looking at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grinning) Keep goin', Mister. He was fallin'  for it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two men burst out laughing and move off together. Bob who has missed the point of this by-play, looks at Klaatu then after the men. As they move out of scene they laugh  loudly at the little boy's confusion. Klaatu takes Bobby' hand to lead him away from the roped-off area.

dialogues.speaker: KLAATU AND BOBBY
dialogues.text: CAMERA FOLLOWS them as they move away through the crowd. As they do so, several newsboys are working their way thr the crowd with newly arrived extras. The boys are calling out the extras: "Police under fire!" "Army put in charge! "Space man still at large!" etc. People are eagerly buyin the papers. Klaatu and Booby watch this as they pass thro the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: EXTRA
dialogues.text: In newsboy's hand. The headline reads: SPACE MAN ELUDES P ARMY PUT IN CHARGE.

dialogues.speaker: ANOTHER EXTRA
dialogues.text: In another newsboy's hand. This headline reads: DISTRICT  UNDER MARTIAL LAW. CONGRESS ACTS AS POLICE CHIEF REIGNS.

dialogues.speaker: KLAATU AND BOBBY
dialogues.text: as they move on away from the excited crowd of people.  Klaatu's reaction has been one of mild curiosity. Bobby l up at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think they'll ever find him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (alter a moment's  pause) I don't know, Bobby. I'm inclined to  doubt it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as they continue  walking) Mr. Carpenter -- what does velocity  mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (preoccupied) Velocity is the time rate of change  of position.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This explanation misses Bobby by several light years. He  glances up at Klaatu blankly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll bet that's the way Professor  Barnhardt talks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pulled out of his reverie, Klaatu glances down at Bobby a smiles apologetically. Bobby grins back at him. Then, as  they walk on a few more steps, Klaatu stops and speaks  thoughtfully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobby -- I have an idea. Let's go  see Professor Barnhardt and find out  how he talks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a half-smile of  accusation) You're just kidding, aren't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wouldn't you like to meet him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, sure I would, but -- (he's to be not going  taken in) Aw, I'll bet you'd be scared.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a private smile) We can scare him more than he can  scare us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobby stares up at him and his face breaks into a broad  admiring grin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I like you, Mr. Carpenter. You're a  real screwball.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: The house is an unimposing old-fashioned structure, shoul on either side by similar one-family dwellings. There is flight of stone steps leading up to the entrance and a la porch across the front of the house. Klaatu and Bobby wal into scene and pause, Klaatu glances at Bobby and Bobby n toward the house. They move on up the steps to the entran

dialogues.speaker: AT FRONT DOOR
dialogues.text: Bobby, all eagerness and excitement, presses the bell. Th wait a moment and there is no answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (disappointed at the  thought) Gee -- maybe he isn't home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobby wanders down the porch and looks into a window.  Fascinated by what he sees, he gestures to Klaatu.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betcha this is where he works--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After a glance at the front door, Klaatu joins Bobby at t window and looks in.

dialogues.speaker: BARNHARDT'S STUDY
dialogues.text: SHOOTING through the window, over the heads of Klaatu and Bobby. The room is more of a workroom than a study. It is comfortably shabby disarray, with papers and books everyw There's a battered old desk and a day bed. One wall is so bookshelves and on the other two are blackboards covered  with a fantastic array of complex equations, graphs and  diagrams.

dialogues.speaker: KLAATU
dialogues.text: His attention has been caught by one of the blackboards a he studies it with great interest and curiosity.

dialogues.speaker: SECTION OF BLACKBOARD
dialogues.text: It is covered with a particularly complicated series of  equations in a chalky scrawl, involving angles of vector, Keplerian ellipses, etc. The final equations are unsolved they have no answers after the "equals" sign. Across are  little printed signs tacked to the blackboard reading: "D erase!" and "Don't touch!"

dialogues.speaker: KLAATU AND BOBBY
dialogues.text: Bewildered, Bobby looks from the blackboard up at Klaatu. Still studying the blackboard, Klaatu is shaking his head and clucking his tonsure as one might at the attempts of child to solve a problem in arithmetic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (indicating the  equations) What does that mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a problem in celestial mechanics.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bet he's the only one in the world  knows the answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (he shakes his head,  smiling) He doesn't know the answer. And he'll  never get it that way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobby moves over to a pair of French doors beyond the win and tries to peer in through the curtained doors. He abse tries the doors and finds them locked. Then he turns away with a disappointed but philosophical shrug.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We probably couldn't get to see him  even if he was home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Bobby moves away from the doors dejectedly, Klaatu put his hand on the knob.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: He's watching Klaatu and his eyes widen at what he sees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in complete surprise) Hey -- where you going?

dialogues.speaker: KLAATU
dialogues.text: He has opened the door and is standing in the doorway, hi hand, still on the knob. He is smiling at Bobby with secr amusement. He's got an idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If he's that difficult to see, perhaps  we ought to leave a calling card.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Klaatu disappears into the study. Amazed, Bobby follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobby watches as Klaatu walks to the blackboard and picks a piece of chalk. As though correcting a schoolboy's work he makes large check marks at several points in each equa

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An efficient-looking middle-aged woman is mounting the st to the entrance, getting her front door key out of her pu when her eye falls on the French doors, which are standin ajar. Puzzled, she starts down the porch toward the doors This woman is Barnhardt's secretary and her name is HILDA Bobby is watching as Klaatu writes across the blackboard a bold hand: Differentiate the equation ( ). Klaatu underlines this comment with a sharp stroke, when stern voice is heard off screen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing in here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Klaatu and Bobby turn in surprise. Standing in the ope French doors is Hilda, eyeing them with stern suspicion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (outraged by Klaatu's  desecration of the  sacred blackboard) How dare you write on that blackboard! (Klaatu eyes her mildly) Do you realize the Professor has  been working on that problem for  weeks?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pleasantly) He'll catch on to it in no time now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (controlling herself  with an effort) How did you get in here? And what do  you want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We came to see Professor Barnhardt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, he's not here. And he won't be  back till this evening. (sternly) I think you'd better leave now.  Unruffled, Klaatu turns to the desk  and scribbles something on a scratch  pad. He tears off the piece of paper  and hands it to Hilda.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You might keep this. (with easy assurance) I think the professor will want to  get in touch with me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With a polite nod he goes out the French doors, followed Bobby. Hilda eyes the door for a moment, then glances dow at the paper in her hand, disturbed and puzzled by this  stranger. Her glance wanders to the blackboard and she pi up an eraser, debating whether to erase Klaatu's correcti At that moment the French door opens and Klaatu sticks hi head in. Startled, Hilda drops the eraser.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pointing to the  blackboard) I wouldn't erase that. The Professor  needs it very badly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And he disappears, leaving Hilda to glare after him in  impotent rage. Deciding that this man is either a crackpo or a menace, she goes to the telephone on the desk and st dialing a number.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Klaatu and Bobby come down the steps and turn into the sidewalk. They are talking and laughing together, but we  can't hear their conversation. CAMERA PANS with them as t move on up the sidewalk, revealing two kids playing hopsc Klaatu watches, fascinated, as he walks by. Then, having  passed the kids, he tries the one-footed, then two-footed hop that characterizes the game.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hilda is talking on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --no, Sergeant, there was no  classified material around, but I  have instructions to report anything  unusual to the police... Yes -- I'm  Professor Barnhardt's secretary. (consulting the paper  in her hand) The man's name is Carpenter -- and  he lives at 1615 St. Street, N.W...  Yes, that's right--

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: Bobby and Klaatu come out of a wooded path into a section the cemetery where the myriad crosses seem to reach into  infinity. They pause for a moment, then Bobby leads the w through one of the rows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: in one of the many rows are crosses that extend beyond CA RANGE. CAMERA MOVES IN on one of the crosses. It bears th name LT. ROBERT BENSON.

dialogues.speaker: KLAATU AND B0BBY
dialogues.text: as they come into scene and look down at the grave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's my father. (Klaatu glances at  the boy, then nods  understandingly) He was killed at a place called Anzio.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Klaatu's glance roves out thoughtfully to the infinite ro of crosses, and his eyes are sad as they return to Bobby.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: Klaatu and Bobby are approaching a bench beside a pathway overhung with trees. Bobby leads the way to the bench and they sit down. Klaatu's eyes stray out to the myriad cros

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Reflectively) Did all these people die in wars?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (somewhat surprised) Sure. Didn't you ever hear of  Arlington Cemetery?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No -- I'm afraid not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (very serious) Mr. Carpenter" -- you don't seem to  know about anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Amused) I'll tell you, Bobby -- I've been  away for a long time. Very far away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it different where you've been? (indicating the  cemetery) Don't they have places like this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (slowly) They have cemeteries. But not like  this one... You see, they don't have  any wars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobby looks at him, puzzled and impressed by this  incomprehensible notion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gee -- that's a good idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His eyes are drawn subconsciously out to the rows of cros Then he turns back to Klaatu with a slow-dawning look of  curiosity, and Klaatu deliberately changes the subject.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What would you like to do this  afternoon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After a moment Bobby's expression changes and he breaks i a broad grin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go to the movies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (he didn't dare hope  for this) No foolin'? Will you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Certainly. (then he hesitates) Tell me, Bobby -- do you have to  have money to go there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobby gives him a look of amazement, then grins, assuming Klaatu was kidding and simply hasn't any money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (eagerly) I've got some money. My mother gave  me two dollars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No -- I want to take you to the  movies. (he takes some objects  out of his pocket) Do you think they'd accept these?

dialogues.speaker: KLAATU'S HAND
dialogues.text: Sparkling in his palm are eight or ten cut diamonds of va sizes.

dialogues.speaker: KLAATU AND BOBBY
dialogues.text: The boy is staring at the stones in wide-eyed amazement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gee -- those look like diamonds!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some places that's what people use  for money. They're easy to carry --  and they don't wear out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (staring at them  fascinated) Bet they're worth about a million  dollars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you give me your two dollars  for a couple of them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a nervous, unsure  smile) Well, sure, but--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boy studies Klaatu's face to see if he's kidding.  Realizing that he's not, Bobby's face takes on a childish shrewd expression -- as though he were about to trade a  jackknife for an ocean liner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (slowly) Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boy takes out two dollar bills and offers them almost challengingly. Klaatu takes the bills and hands Bobby two good-sized Diamonds. They study their new acquisitions wi interest. Bobby looks up from his diamonds to steal a gui glance at Klaatu.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's not say anything to my mother  about this, Mr. Carpenter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mildly curious) Why not, Bobby?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gravely) She doesn't like me to steal from  people.

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: Shooting toward the curb as a police prowl car drives up stops in front of the boardinghouse. A Detective in  plainclothes gets out and gestures to the uniformed Drive to pull up the street a way and wait. The Driver nods and the car moves off as the Detective crosses the sidewalk t the boardinghouse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the Detective mounts the steps he glances through a wi into the living room. Klaatu can be seen reading to Bobby who is perched happily on the arm of Klaatu's chair. The  Detective moves to the front door ant rings the bell. The is the sound of running feet and in a moment the door is  opened and Bobby appears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Carpenter come home yet?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (studying the man  curiously) Yeah -- he's right inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell him I'd like to see him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling out) Mr. Carpenter--! (to the Detective) Come on in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Detective steps inside and Bobby closes the door, as  Klaatu appears from the living room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your name Carpenter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (puzzled that anyone  should know him) Yes. (then recalling, with  a smile of  satisfaction) Oh -- I suppose Professor Barnhardt's  looking far me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dryly, with grim  emphasis) I been looking for you all afternoon.

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: An inexpensive convertible -- a 1948 Ford, or Chevrolet - drives up and stops in front of the house. Helen and Tom in it.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN AND TOM
dialogues.text: You get the feeling that Helen and Ton have spent a very  enjoyable day together and are reluctant to say goodnight Tom puts his arm around her and kisses her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (fondly) It was a wonderful day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You still haven't answered my  question.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (warmly sincere) You know how I feel, Tom. I just  want to think it over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boss is leaving for Chicago  tomorrow. If I could tell him I was  getting married -- with two dependents--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling) You're a good salesman -- but I've  got to think about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A good insurance salesman wouldn't  give you time to think.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With a smile and, a quick kiss, Helen gets out of the car

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
